title: How to Distill

steps.headline: Find a large pot with a lid.
steps.description: The biggest pot you can get your hands on will allow you to distill larger amounts of liquid. The pot should at least be large enough to hold another smaller container like a metal mixing bowl. If you have a curved lid that will cover the pot, use that instead of a flat lid. The shape of a curved lid will help in collecting condensation toward the center. If you can't find a curved lid, you can use some aluminum foil and shape it over a large bowl to get a curved shape. Then you can place the foil, curved side down, over the pot and hold it in place with the lid. This will help to direct the condensed water toward the center and your collection container.

steps.headline: Place a collection container inside the large pot.
steps.description: Select a container that can withstand boiling temperatures. You will likely want to elevate the collection container toward the top of the pot. You can place a small rack in the bottom of the pot and prop your container on top of it. You can even use a brick or similar object since it won't be in contact with the distilled liquid. You can also drill a hole in the lid and use a length of tubing to collect the distilled liquid in a separate container. However, you have to be willing to put holes in your cookware to do so.

steps.headline: Pour the dirty water into the large pot.
steps.description: Be sure not to get any of the dirty liquid into the collection container. You will only want to fill the pot so that the water level is a couple inches below the height of your collection container. If the water is too close to the height of the collection container, it might splash into the container of distilled water and contaminate it.

steps.headline: Place the lid upside-down over the pot.
steps.description: By placing the lid upside-down, the curved angle will help direct the water vapor toward the center as it collects and falls back into your collection pot. A transparent lid is ideal, as it will allow you to see what is happening. You can also place some ice packs or cool water on top of the lid to help the vapor cool faster and return to a liquid form.

steps.headline: Bring the water to a boil.
steps.description: Turn on the stove and heat the water. Monitor the temperature of the water and keep it at a slow boil. You want to avoid heating the water too much and having the dirty water splashing into your collection pot. Adjust the temperature as needed.

steps.headline: Boil the contents until the liquid is almost gone.
steps.description: Do not boil the pot dry or you will risk causing permanent damage to it. Let the distilled liquid cool. It may take several hours of boiling to collect a significant amount of liquid, so be patient.

steps.headline: Know the boiling point of the substance you want to distill.
steps.description: Generally, simple distillation (as described here) will work for substances that boil below 200C. Above that, many compounds can decompose, so a vacuum distillation is recommended. If you don't know the boiling point of the substance you want to distill, a very rough rule of thumb is that a compound's boiling point rises by around 15 C for each carbon that's added to the chain. Find a compound structurally similar to the one you want to distill, and add 15 C per additional carbon.

steps.headline: Pour the liquid into a distilling flask.
steps.description: Take the liquid you want to purify and pour it into the distilling flask. Only fill the flask between half and two-thirds full, so the liquid does not take too long to evaporate.

steps.headline: Place the distilling flask over the heat source.
steps.description: You can use a stand to hold the flask above the burner or heat source. You may also want to use a basin filled with sand to rest the distilling flask on instead of directly over the burner. This will prevent the liquid from boiling too violently as the sand helps to evenly distribute the heat.

steps.headline: Connect the condenser.
steps.description: Attach one end of the condenser to the vent at the top of the distilling flask. The condenser should be angled downward to help the water flow toward the collection flask. The condenser has 2 tubes, one inside of the other. The condenser will transfer the vapor to the collection container and help to cool it back into a liquid form.

steps.headline: Connect the "pig" if you're doing vacuum distillation.
steps.description: This is a piece of glassware with a vacuum adapter, an inlet, and several outlets for connecting flasks. Make sure to grease the joint between the pig and the condenser, so you can change fractions easily.

steps.headline: Place the collection beaker beneath the condenser.
steps.description: Place the cup or flask beneath the opening on the end of the condenser. The liquid will drip out as the vapor cools and collect in the cup below. You can also choose to connect the collection container directly to the condenser if you have the materials to do so (if doing a vacuum distillation, you will have to do this to maintain system vacuum).

steps.headline: Turn on the heat source, and connect the vacuum if applicable.
steps.description: Bring the liquid to a boil and monitor the temperature. You may want to use a thermometer to monitor the temperature and keep the liquid just above the boiling point so it doesn't heat too quickly. Adjust the burner level if needed.

steps.headline: Monitor the temperature of the distillation using the thermometer.
steps.description: For a while the thermometer's temperature will not change, but once enough vapour builds up, the temperature should rise rapidly, and then level off. This value is the compound's boiling point at the pressure.

steps.headline: Collect the distilled liquid.
steps.description: Turn the heat off once the distilling flask is mostly empty. Do not heat the flask until dry as you could damage the glass. Let the liquid cool in the collection flask. If you want the collected liquid to cool faster, you can place the collection container in a bath of cold or ice water.

steps.headline: Watch the temperature.
steps.description: If it starts shooting up again, switch out receiving flasks. This means that one compound in the mixture has finished distilling out, and that another higher-boiling fraction is now coming off. When the temperature levels off, switch flasks again -- this will result in more pure factions. When the temperature starts to fall, and does not rise for a considerable period of time, the distillation is over. At this point turn off the heat, depressurize the system (if applicable) and check your factions.

steps.headline: Check the purity of your factions.
steps.description: Use proton nuclear magnetic resonance and examine your spectra. Do the factions look clean? If yes you're done. If not, you may need to redistill, or use an alternative method of purification, such as column chromatography.
